text: So here’s the problem,
<@U0N7D6F50>_ has grown really huge
my cheap $10 vps with Jenkins is having trouble building/deploying the project
we need to control <@U0N7D6F50> ’s borders
I’m guessing that Gradle runs out of memory before the build completes
<https://androidchat.slack.com/files/nish/F1DEL1SJD/-.txt>
> Gradle build daemon disappeared unexpectedly
:joy:
/gif vanish
So i’m open to ideas on how to restructure the project so that this doesn’t happen
<@U053PPGDC>: gave an interesting Idea, what if we could publish binaries?
for plugins
is there some kind of open source publishing server we could hook into?
I’d prefer something self hosted
what if you build on travis
Doesn’t fix the root of the problem
no use constantly rebuilding the plugins
The point of having them decoupled is to manage them separately
maven libs are binaries right?
yeah
we could all push them to maven then
Well here is my idea
- <@U0N7D6F50> is growing into a kind of ecosystem
someone makes a nice plugin, you want it in your server, you get the jar add it to your deployment
what this means is we need some kind of publishing platform
that’s like the root of the problem here
a linkbait maven repo.
something like that
so why not have that, and have CI build the plugins separately
then publish to repo
and linkbait works kind of like maven or npm and uses a plugins.json to fetch deps
It’s pretty big thinking, but it solves the problem :confused:
for maven - you can either use an artifactory to host it or I’ve seen it done with pure s3 as well
<https://www.jfrog.com/open-source/>

attachments.title: Artifactory – The Open Source Maven Repository Manager
attachments.text: Host/proxy for Maven Repository. Integration with Ant, Gradle, Ivy, with fine-grained permission control. 1-minute setup!
attachments.fallback: Managing your binaries: Artifactory – The Open Source Maven Repository Manager

text: might be the best idea
<http://www.yegor256.com/2015/09/07/maven-repository-amazon-s3.html>

attachments.title: How to Set Up a Private Maven Repository in Amazon S3
attachments.text: Amazon S3 is a perfect place for keeping private Maven artifacts, automatically deploying them there, and making them available through <http://s3auth.com|s3auth.com>.
attachments.fallback: yegor256: How to Set Up a Private Maven Repository in Amazon S3

My advice, if you want to do java
